summary_visit.AdmissionSummary: Patient is a 51-year-old male with a history of liver cirrhosis secondary to chronic Hepatitis C infection. He is experiencing worsening ascites and hepatic encephalopathy, requiring urgent evaluation for a liver transplant.

current_diagnoses.treatment: Currently on diuretics, beta blockers, and lactulose. MELD score: 24.
Lactulose and rifaximin. Cognitive function is progressively worsening.
Paracentesis required every two weeks. On diuretics.

past_diagnoses.treatment: Successfully treated with direct-acting antivirals in 2019.
Managed with beta blockers. Under control.

medications.name: Lactulose
medications.reason: To reduce ammonia levels and prevent hepatic encephalopathy.

medications.name: Rifaximin
medications.reason: To prevent hepatic encephalopathy by reducing gut bacteria.

medications.name: Propranolol
medications.reason: To manage portal hypertension and prevent variceal bleeding.

medications.name: Pantoprazole
medications.reason: Proton pump inhibitor for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and to prevent stress ulcers.

medications.name: Furosemide
medications.reason: Diuretic to manage fluid retention associated with liver disease.

medications.name: Spironolactone
medications.reason: Diuretic to manage ascites and prevent fluid accumulation.

notes.note_content: Patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of liver cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use disorder, presenting for evaluation for liver transplant. Physical exam reveals mild ascites and jaundice. Lab results show elevated liver enzymes. Patient is being worked up for liver transplant eligibility.

Patient appears stable, but reports mild discomfort in the abdomen. Vital signs are within normal limits, with the exception of slightly elevated blood pressure (142/90). Patient is tolerating clear liquids well. Monitoring for any signs of worsening ascites or encephalopathy.

Reviewed current medications. Patient is on lactulose 30 mL BID for hepatic encephalopathy, spironolactone 100 mg daily for ascites, and omeprazole 20 mg daily for GERD. Plan to start tacrolimus post-transplant and discontinue spironolactone at that time.

Patient is on a low-sodium diet due to cirrhosis. Appetite is adequate, and patient reports no difficulty swallowing or digesting current diet. Will continue to monitor nutritional intake and recommend protein supplementation if albumin remains low.

Performed a paracentesis due to increased abdominal distension and discomfort. Approximately 2 liters of ascitic fluid was removed. Fluid sent to lab for analysis. Patient tolerated the procedure well and will be monitored for signs of infection or hypotension.

Patient is scheduled for a liver transplant. Pre-operative assessment shows stable vitals, no active infections, and normal kidney function. Blood products and medications have been ordered for the procedure. Discussed risks and benefits of surgery with the patient and family. Patient consents to the procedure.

Patient is post-op day 1 from liver transplant. Incision site clean and dry with no signs of infection. Pain is well-controlled with IV morphine. Patient has been started on clear fluids and is ambulating with assistance. Will continue to monitor vital signs and urine output.

Consulted for post-transplant infection risk management. Patient is at high risk for bacterial and fungal infections due to immunosuppression. Initiating prophylactic antibiotics and antifungal medication. Will monitor for any signs of infection, including fever, cough, or abnormal lab values.

Post-liver transplant medication regimen reviewed. Tacrolimus started at 2 mg BID for immunosuppression. Continue lactulose for encephalopathy, and added pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis. Will monitor drug levels and adjust doses as necessary.

Post-transplant nutrition assessment. Patient tolerating solid food well. Continuing low-sodium, high-protein diet to promote healing and avoid fluid retention. Will recheck albumin levels tomorrow and provide supplementation if needed.

recommendation_notes: Patient showing decreased symptoms of GERD.
No significant acid reflux observed over the last 3 months.
